projectDesc.p: "夜半樂" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the Tune “Midnight Joy”
Frozen clouds dim the sky,
a thin sail,
departs the riverside on a whim,
crossing a myriad valleys and a thousand canyons.
In the depth of Yue streams,
raging waves gradually dies down,
a favorable wind suddenly rises.
I then hear the traveling tradesmen calling each other.
The lone sail hangs high;
on a floating boat,
I swiftly pass the southern bank.
In the view, the wine shop banner swing,
a small smoke-surrounding village,
rows of frosty trees.
The setting sun retreats,
the fishermen strike the side of the boat and return.
Withered lotuses fall apart,
fading willows cover and reveal.
On the bank, in two or three,
are girls doing laundry.
Avoiding the travelers,
shy, they smile, chatting to each other.
Being here brings back my thoughts.
I have lightly abandoned the embroidered chamber.
Like a duckweed in the waves, I have nowhere to stay.
I sigh upon the thought of reunion,
what can substantiate those earnest words?
Wretched, is the heart in parting,
vainly regretting that the year has come to the end and the time to return is delayed.
I let my watery eyes gaze,
at the long distant road to the capital.
The cry of the strayed wild goose extends long, lingering in the vast evening sky.
